channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [TIKA-1420] Add Metadata Extraction to Arbitrary Parsers
item.description:
Suppose you wish to extract information from arbitrary file types and add it to a Metadata Object. This type of task is best handled by a... Handler. But, Handlers do not have access to the Metadata Object passed to a Parser.

So, I see a few ways we could do using existing functionality.

1) Make an intermediate XML representation of the desired metadata in a handler, then convert the XML to the Metadata after parsing.

2) Create a second Parser which extracts the desired information.
a) Assume the Handler passed to this Parser is already filled with content. So, we could simply get whatever content from the Handler and populate the Metadata directly.
b) Create a new Stream in the first Parser to pass to the second, which in turn populates the Metadata.

None of these options seem ideal. Is there a better way to handle this scenario? Or, can we create some sort of... wrapper for a Handler which can accept a Metadata Object to populate directly?
item.summary: Add Metadata Extraction to Arbitrary Parsers

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Are you envisioning something that will look for certain kinds of information in the primary parser's output (eg snippets of xhtml), that will then be used to build the metadata? Or would the information to go into the metadata come from somewhere else?
That's exactly what I'm imagining. As an example use case, I'd like to extract phone numbers from a document and add them to the Metadata.

right now the metadata goes into the <head><meta ..></head> portion of the XHTML- would be nice somehow to have some callback after the handler as transformed the XHTML to then fill the metadata somehow with info that it didn't have before. Tyler and I talked about this the other day thanks for creating the issue.

I don't see why you couldn't do it as a decorating handler that also took the metadata object, eg

    Metadata metadata = new Metadata();
    PhoneExtractingContentHandler handler = new PhoneExtractingContentHandler(metadata, realContentHandler)
    (new DefaultParser()).parse(input, metadata, handler, new ParseContext());

That way, it'd have the metadata object to hand to populate additionally, and would have the real content handler to pass the rest/all the normal content too
Nick that's a great idea. Let's work towards this Tyler Palsulich

Nick Burch, sounds good! So, would that involve overriding the characters method to 1) check the characters for a phone number, add them to the metadata, and 2) pass that to the underlying Handler's character's method?

Checking for phone numbers would involve adding an additional dependency on libphonenumber, an ALv2.0 "library for parsing, formatting, storing and validating international phone numbers."

For now, I'd suggest putting this into the Examples package, then the additional dependency should be fine.

Characters wise, you might need to use some sort of rolling buffer for the detection, in case the number gets split between multiple character calls (eg part of it is styled, part not, so in different tags, or just fits across a text size boundary), but for the initial version just checking the characters before passing them on should work fine
Initial example added in r1627397.

Since it's an example, it might be good to put in a hefty amount of class-level JavaDoc explaining how it works, why you might want to use something like that etc!

Just made some more updates in r1627446. I added a lot more documentation, removed the dependency on libphonenumber, and added custom phone number deobfuscation code. The solution given assumes that the file's text will fit in a String, which may not be true. But, we can iterate on that later.

In my opinion, this is worth more than just an example. Parse any file and get a list of phone numbers out.

Any reason this is in examples? I think it could easily go into tika-core - no reason this content handler is any less generic than e.g., the LinkExtractor?
Now it's dependency free, don't see why it can't be in core!
Thanks Nick! Tyler Palsulich when you get a chance if you can move to core that would be awesome
Thanks Nick Burch and Chris A. Mattmann. I'll move them over tomorrow, resolve this issue, and close the RB.

Moved over in r1628340. I moved the extractor and deobfuscation code to tika-core, moved the extractor's test to tika-parsers, and added a new example (from the RB) of using the extractor to get all phone numbers from all files in a directory (with the ability to run the example from the command line).
